Award.AwardTitle: Mixed-Status Families and Citizenship in the Contemporary Migration Experience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
There are 2.3 million mixed-status families in the US, in which the uncertain legal status of some members influences opportunities and resources for all, including permanent residents and US citizens. A focus on individuals in US law and policy largely overlooks cumulative ripple effects on families, although individuals are always embedded within these complex social units. This study examines how mixed-status families experience specific policies related to health care and education, and seeks to understand how they collectively navigate opportunities and obstacles. It is necessary to understand the experiences of these families -- including and especially the impacts on some 4.5 million US citizen children -- in order to ensure equitable application of policy and to reduce disparities.

Using mixed-status families as a primary unit of analysis, this project advances scholarship on how juridical categories shape socialization to identities within the domestic sphere as well as in relation to public institutions such as health care and education. This ethnographic study examines how families actively negotiate institutions by employing a longitudinal, three-year design. Data from multiple members of 40 mixed-status families will be examined across two points in time. This will be contextualized through participant observation and interviews with 50 service providers and community experts. This study seeks to transform theories of migration and law by shifting the focus from individuals to families, better revealing social impacts and how difference are shaped at the family level. Bridging experiences at the micro-familial with those at the policy level will result in advances for understanding the contemporary migration experience and theoretical concerns in the social science of law.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project concludes that novel theoretical contributions to the study of migration and practices of citizenship can be made through the analysis of mixed-status family dynamics. It illustrates how juridical categories of legal status stratify resources and shape members’ socialization in relation to institutions such as education and health care, as well as within the domestic sphere. The project addresses theoretical concerns central to studies of law, cultural anthropology, and sociology, including the (re)production of families, the character of negotiations between individuals and state regimes, citizenship and belonging, and “illegality.” This research finds that the construction of “illegality” for some members in a family influences opportunities and resources for everyone, including spillover effects for legal residents and U.S. citizens. Bureaucratic disentitlement is one way by which individuals may be deprived of their statutory rights or entitlements; this involves unnecessarily complicating processes, withholding information, providing misinformation, or isolating individuals. This actively blocks the incorporation of mixed-status families into US society. Incorporation is also impacted by aggressive immigration enforcement practices, since deportation critically affects the economic and emotional base of the family unit. Deportation regimes are profoundly efficient in provoking fear through a combination of targeting a few while fostering an enduring sense of danger and precarity for many. In addition, social relationships are affected by the “illegality” of family members. Feelings of embarrassment, shame, or fear may affect people’s ability to form strong and trusting social bonds. A person’s subjectivity—their everyday sense of being in the world—may also be acutely affected if they are part of a mixed-status family. Several U.S. citizens relayed that they “felt undocumented too” by virtue of their family members’ status. Nonetheless, while illegality impacts everyone in the family, they are not simply passive recipients of this circumstance. Through their resilience and creative responses, people in mixed-status families actively contest and resist juridical categories and amend the circulating hegemonic structures of meanings concerning the law. Finally, this project emphasized that configurations of “illegality” and their effect on incorporation are geographically specific and historically contingent.
